description: From Latin dilapidātus, past participle of dilapidō (“I destroy with stones”), from dis- (“intensifier”) + lapidō (“I stone”), from lapis (“stone”).

verbs.description: dilapidate (third-person singular simple present dilapidates, present participle dilapidating, simple past and past participle dilapidated)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause to become ruined or put into disrepair.
examples: If the bishop, parson, or vicar, etc., dilapidates the buildings, or cuts down the timber of the patrimony […]
The patrimony of the bishopric of Oxon was much dilapidated.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, archaic) To fall into ruin or disuse.
